title: 107_hr5557
content: The "Armed Forces Tax Fairness Act of 2002" allows special rules for members of the uniformed services and foreign service when determining exclusion of gain from the sale of their principal residence. The "Armed Forces Tax Fairness Act of 2002" provides special rules for members of the uniformed services and foreign service regarding the exclusion of gain from the sale of their principal residence. This includes the suspension of the 5-year period for property ownership during qualified official extended duty, with a maximum extension of 5 years. The "Armed Forces Tax Fairness Act of 2002" suspends the 5-year period for property ownership during qualified official extended duty, defined as duty at least 150 miles from the property or residing under Government orders in Government quarters. The term 'uniformed services' and 'foreign service' are defined accordingly. The term 'member of the Foreign Service' is defined in relation to the Foreign Service Act of 1980. 'Extended duty' is defined as active duty exceeding 180 days or for an indefinite period. An election under special rules allows for the suspension of the 5-year property ownership period during qualified official extended duty. The amendment allows for the revocation of an election regarding property. The effective date is retroactive, and there is a waiver of limitations for tax refunds or credits resulting from the amendment. The amendment allows for revocation of an election regarding property, with a retroactive effective date and a waiver of limitations for tax refunds or credits if a claim is filed before the close of the period. SEC. 3. RESTORATION OF FULL EXCLUSION FROM GROSS INCOME OF DEATH GRATUITY PAYMENT. Amends section 134 of the Internal Revenue Code to exclude adjustments to death gratuity payments under certain conditions. Effective for deaths after September 10, 2001. SEC. 4. EXCLUSION FOR AMOUNTS RECEIVED UNDER DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE HOMEOWNERS ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. Section 132(a) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include a new paragraph (8) for qualified military base realignment and closure fringe benefits. This fringe benefit is defined as payments under section 1013 of the Demonstration Cities and Metropolitan Development. The amendments made by this section apply to payments made after the enactment of this Act to offset adverse effects on housing values due to military base realignment or closure. Expansion of combat zone filing rules to contingency operations. Expansion of combat zone filing rules to include individuals deployed outside the United States away from their permanent duty station while participating in designated contingency operations. Amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code to accommodate this change. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code expand filing rules to include individuals deployed outside the US for designated contingency operations. Effective date applies to acts not expired before enactment of the Act. SEC. 6 amends the membership requirement for tax exemption for certain veterans' organizations to include ancestors or lineal descendants. Effective for taxable years after enactment. SEC. 7 clarifies treatment of certain dependent care assistance programs. Section 134(b) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include dependent care assistance programs for qualified military benefits. Conforming amendments are made to sections 134(b)(3)(A), 3121(a)(18), and 3306(b)(13) of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. No inference can be drawn regarding the tax treatment of amounts under the program described in section 134(b)(4) for taxable years before January 1, 2002. SEC. 8. PROTECTION OF SOCIAL SECURITY. The amounts transferred to any trust fund under title II of the Social Security Act shall be determined as if this Act had not been enacted. This Act, H.R. 5557, aims to amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to provide special rules for members of the uniformed services and Foreign Service regarding the exclusion of gain from the sale of a principal residence and the tax-exempt status of death gratuity payments.
